description: Middle English adverten, from Old French advertir (“to notice”), from Latin advertere (“to turn toward”). See also adverse.

verbs.description: advert (third-person singular simple present adverts, present participle adverting, simple past and past participle adverted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To take notice, to pay attention (to). [from 15th c.]
examples: At a time when creation seems to be endangered in so many ways through human activity, we should consciously advert to this dimension of Sunday, too.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To turn attention to, to take notice of (something). [15th–19th c.]

examples: ‘I have before suggested that a genuine blackguard is never without a pocket-handkerchief. But it is not to this fact that I now especially advert.’
